Theory¶

Let us assume we want to calculate the thermal conductivity of a bar with length L and cross-sectional area A, subjected to a difference of temperatue \(\Delta T\). At the hot contact (HC), there will be outgoing thermal flux \(\mathbf{J}(\mathbf{r})\), which is related to the effective thermal conductivity \(\kappa_{eff}\) via Fourier’s law, i.e.

(1)¶\[\kappa_{eff} = -\frac{L}{\Delta T A}\int_{HC} dS \, \mathbf{J}(\mathbf{r}) \cdot \mathbf{\hat{n}}\]

Due to the presence of classical phonon size effects, heat transport is not diffusive, and \(\mathbf{J}(\mathbf{r})\) needs to be calculated by the Boltzmann transport equation (BTE). OpenBTE is based on the mean-free-path formulation of the BTE. The starting point of its derivation is the standard steady-state BTE in the relaxation time approximation

(2)¶\[\mathbf{v}_\lambda \cdot \nabla f_\lambda (\mathbf{r}) = \frac{1}{\tau_\lambda}\left[f^0_\lambda(T) - f_\lambda(\mathbf{r}) \right],\]

where \(\lambda\) collectively describes phonon wave vector \(\mathbf{q}\) and polarization \(p\), \(\mathbf{v}_\lambda\) is the group velocity, \(f_\lambda(\mathbf{r})\) is the non-equilibrium distribution function. The equilibrium function \(f_\lambda^0(\mathbf{r})\) is the Bose-Einstain distribution at the effective temperature \(T(\mathbf{r})\), i.e.

(3)¶\[f^0_\lambda(\mathbf{r})=\left(e^{\frac{\hbar \omega_\lambda}{k_B T(\mathbf{r})}} + 1 \right)^{-1},\]

where \(k_B\) is the Boltzmann constant and \(\hbar\omega_\lambda\) is the phonon energy. Energy conservation requires \(\nabla \cdot \mathbf{J}(\mathbf{r}) = 0\), where the total phonon flux \(\mathbf{J}(\mathbf{r})\) is defined by

(4)¶\[\mathbf{J}(\mathbf{r}) = \int \hbar\omega_\lambda \mathbf{v}_\lambda f_\lambda(\mathbf{r}) \frac{d\mathbf{q}}{8\pi^3}.\]

After multiplying both sides of Eq. (2) by \(\hbar \omega_\lambda\) and integrating over the B. Z., we have

(5)¶\[\int \frac{d\mathbf{q}}{8\pi^3} \frac{\hbar\omega_\lambda}{\tau_\lambda} \left[f_\lambda^0(T) -f_\lambda(\mathbf{r})\right] = 0.\]

In practice, one has to compute \(T(\mathbf{r})\) such as Eq. (5) is satisfied. To simplify this task, we assume that the temperatures variation are small such that the equilibrium distribution can be approximated by its first-order Taylor expansion, i.e.

(6)¶\[f_\lambda^0(T) \approx f_\lambda^0(T_0) + \frac{C_\lambda}{\hbar\omega_\lambda}\left([T(\mathbf{r})-T_0 \right],\]

where \(C_\lambda(T_0)\) is the heat capacity at a reference temperature \(T_0\). After including Eq. (6) into Eq. (5), we have

(7)¶\[T(\mathbf{r}) -T_0 = \int \frac{d\mathbf{q}}{8\pi^3} a_\lambda \frac{\hbar \omega_\lambda}{C_\lambda}\left[f_\lambda(\mathbf{r}) - f_\lambda^0(T_0)\right],\]

where

(8)¶\[a_\lambda = \frac{C_\lambda}{\tau_\lambda} \left[\int \frac{d\mathbf{q}}{8\pi^3} \frac{C_\lambda}{\tau_\lambda} \right]^{-1}.\]

The BTE under a small applied temperature gradients can be then derived after including Eqs. (7)-(6) into Eq. (2)

(9)¶\[\tau_\lambda \mathbf{v}_\lambda \cdot \nabla f_\lambda (\mathbf{r}) +f_\lambda(\mathbf{r}) - f_\lambda^0(T_0) = \frac{C_\lambda}{\hbar \omega_\lambda}\int \frac{d\mathbf{q}'}{8\pi^3} a_\lambda' \frac{\hbar \omega_{\lambda'}}{C_{\lambda'}}\left[f_{\lambda'}(\mathbf{r}) - f_{\lambda'}^0(T_0)) \right].\]

Upon the change of variable

(10)¶\[T_\lambda(\mathbf{r}) = \frac{\hbar\omega_\lambda}{C_\lambda}\left[f_\lambda(\mathbf{r})- f_\lambda^0(T_0) \right],\]

we obtain the temperature formulation of the BTE

(11)¶\[\mathbf{F}_\lambda \cdot \nabla T_\lambda(\mathbf{r}) + T_\lambda(\mathbf{r}) - \int \frac{d\mathbf{q}'}{8\pi^3} a_{\lambda'}T_{\lambda'}(\mathbf{r}) = 0,\]

where \(\mathbf{F}_\lambda=\mathbf{v}_\lambda \tau_\lambda\). Within this formulation, the thermal flux becomes

(12)¶\[\mathbf{J}(\mathbf{r}) = \int \frac{d\mathbf{q}}{8\pi^3} \frac{C_\lambda}{\tau_\lambda} T_\lambda(\mathbf{r}) \mathbf{F}_\lambda.\]
